Journalism as a Profession.
There are so many kinds of newspaper
work and so many classes of publications,
that any general discussion of this subject
is impossible in the limited space allowed.
Leaving out, however, all kinds and classes
of papers save those of commanding influence and power for good, the field is one in
which what may be called "the personal
equation" will tell the story of success or
failure. And so, if a young man, looking
about for a life vocation, should ask me to
advise him whether or not to adopt journalism as a profession, I should first want to
know that young man better than one father
in a thousand knows his favorite son. I
should want to measure his capacity and
character and test the metal of his ambition.
There is room for usefulness all the way up
from the bottom, but for a man of real ability and ambition the only places in journalism worth having are at the top or very
near the top. These he can never attain
unless endowed by nature with certain peculiar gifts. What Horace said of the poet
is true of the journalist.
It is safe to say that on few other practical questions is the popular idea concerning the requisites for success more vague.
Nine men out of ten, even among the more
intelligent, are under the impression that
the mere ability to write good English is
the main, if not the only, qualification required for successful newspaper work. As
a matter of fact, my observation leads me
to believe that mere ability to write well
is a minor factor in counting up the qualifications for success in this line of work.
The main thing is to know what to write
about—in other words, to know what constitutes news, what the public really wants
to read and be advised about. Some of the
most successful men at the top seldom write
a line. They tell the men at .the bottom
what to say.
Another factor in journalistic success of
scarce less importance than to know what
is news and what to discuss, may be expressed in the single word—character. Love of

truth for truth's sake is indispensable to
commanding influence in this field of human
endeavor. There are hundreds of men with
the gift of knowing how to write and even
of what to write about, and who at the same
time may be real lovers of truth, who can
never reach the top. For your truly great
editor, or manager—or whatever the man
who really controls, directs and inspires a
newspaper may choose to call himself—will
be found to be intensely patriotic and in full
sympathy with his brother man. Indeed, I
make bold to declare that no enduring success was ever made in the upbuilding of
any newspaper or periodical if its real head
lacked either patriotism or philanthropy.
The motto of all permanently great publications is "The greatest good to the greatest
number;'' and is lined up to "without variableness or shadow of turning." The public
does not obey the golden rule to the extent
of doing good for evil. If you prove its
friend, it will be yours. If you are indifferent to its welfare, it is deaf, dumb and blind
to your interests. If you slap it in the face
it will turn upon you and destroy you.
Another desideratum is sense of proportion; a knowledge of relativity. The public is always the final judge of what it
wants. To know what the public wants to
read and be advised about is a condition
precedent to a knowledge of the relative
value of news and of the relative importance
of subjects for editorial discussion. Lack
of this single requisite has kept many a
bright and capable man in a subordinate
The tyro generally
position all his life.
gives the greatest prominence to items and
subjects which appeal to him, and it generally happens that these are the things in
whcih the public is least concerned. "The
proper study of mankind is man" applies
to journalism as to other callings. To keep
in touch with public sentiment it is necessary to study. man collectively.
That the requisites for success in journalism are peculiar and generally little comprehended is attested by the fact that so

many men of real capacity try it and fail.
It is not perhaps too much to say that there
is a larger percentage of men who after failing in journalism succeed in other lines than
of those who redeem early failure in any
other calling.
The successful journalist must not only
know the truth, love the truth, know what
is worth while and what is not, have at heart
the public welfare, be imbued with a discerning sense of proportion and relativity,
but he must be progressive, or all these
qualities will count for naught. He who
succeeds in any line must be alert and wide
awake to changing conditions. Every hour
changes the relations of people and things
Ties are sundered,
toward one another.
sympathies are transferred, the old are passing and the new are edging in. The newspaper man, more than all others, is required
to keep in closest touch with ever changing
conditions, to keep familiar with the kaleidoscopic complexities of modern civilization.
The true journalist must be able to discern
the signs of the times as they relate to every
form of human endeavor. He must be the
seer and the prophet, the interpreter and
the orator, the teacher, the preacher. All
this, of course, if he aims at the highest
measure of success.
There are, however, found in newspaper
offices all over the land men who esteem it
to their credit if they have for a number of
years filled the same position on the same
paper, as, for instance, a police reporter or
a "sporting editor," who has become a
local authority in his specialty. Indeed, I
have known various successful "political
editors" who did not even attempt to write
their own stories but who were news gatherers of such marvellous energy and success
that they were regarded as invaluable members of the staff. But these are subordinate
members of the profession.
I am considering this question only from
the standpoint of a college-bred man who is
looking about for a career in life which seems
to him worthy of a high ambition—an ambition which nothing but the highest achievement will satisfy. To such a young man I
should say it is worth while to find out
whether you are endowed with the journalistic instinct. This can be done only by
trying. Begin at the bottom. "Get a job"
as a reporter. Don't for a moment harbor

the thought that you know a little bit about
the work. Do what you are told to do as
if your life depended on it. If it be in you
to succeed you will be discovered and invited
to step up higher. But don't expect premature appreciation, for if you do your certain disappointment will be painful and perhaps discouraging.
It goes without saying that the career of
a journalist is extremely attractive to the
man of capacity, equipment and high resolve.
Few positions in our national life are more
to be desired than those which have been
held by a Greeley or a Dana or those that
are now held by such men as Henry Watterson or Richard H. Edmonds—types of men
who, though in widely different fields, are
profoundly impressing the thought of to-day
and exerting a powerful influence for good,
as they see it, on the public mind,
In the changing conditions in journalism
as in every other line of endeavor, it may not
be possible for a Greeley, a Dana or a Watterson or an Edmonds to soon appear again
in the journalistic field, but it is inconceivable that men of keen perceptions, broad
sympathy and high ideality, if intensely in
earnest can fail of achieving a certain measure of success, and I really believe there
never has been a greater demand for ability
of the highest order nor a time when faithfulness, patriotism and righteousness were
more needed in journalism than at the present time, and I believe the rewards will be
as great and as satisfying as they ever have
been, even if they may not come in exactly
the same way. The young man who chooses
journalism as his career may therefore have
no fear that the field of his endeavors or the
range of his achievements will be small, if
his mind is on his work and his whole heart
in it. If he have quick apprehension (instinctively and acquired), if he have broad
sympathies and high ideals, he should be
able to organize himself into an efficient journalistic force, though he may never quite
reach the top. With these qualifications he
will be able to write in a manner that the
public will appreciate and understand; he
will be able to treat of the subjects in which
they are interested, and will be able to command their confidence and respect; because
of the loyalty and devotion to humanity
which are his.

A Bunch of Blue Violets.
They sat in the farthest corner of the spacious parlor, out of the glare of the brilliant
chandelier. In manly tones, he poured forth
burning words in her ear. She bent her
graceful head, and nervously twirled the
little bunch of blue violets he had brought
her.
But at last she stopped him.
'Harry," she said firmly, "it cannot be.
You know how bitterly father opposes it, and
I must consider his will in the matter. And
then, too," she added, while her bright eyes
filled with tears, "since mother is gone, there
is no one to take care of him but me, and
I cannot desert him now."
On hearing this, Henry Underwood's heart
smote him at the thought that he could wish
to tear this noble girl away from where duty
called her. He wondered how he could find
it in him to press her further; though her
devotion to her gruff old father, raised his
admiration of her, if possible, still higher.
"Edith," he said, as he finally rose to depart, "I can wait. May I also hope?"
Edith Upton. stood in the broad doorway,
her tall shapely figure revealed against the
background of the lighted hall. She did not
answer his question, for, at that moment, a
stout old gentleman, leaning heavily on a
cane, came hobbling up the steps. Henry
instantly recognized him as Mr. Upton, and,
with a word of greeting, was about to pass
out. But the old man blocked his way.
"Young man, whoever you are," he
growled, pretending not to know him,"your
visits here are not welcome."
Underwood was about to make some
haughty reply, but Edith was too quick for
him.
"Father," she said imperatively, catching
him by the arm, "you must not stand here
in the night air. Come inside."
The old man was strangely pliant in her
hands, and soon Underwood saw her pull
him inside and shut the door, not, however,
without giving him a parting look, as he
went slowly down the steps.
It was with a heavy tread that young
Underwood walked home that night. His
affair of the heart had come to a head, and he

had not won. Yet something told him that,
were she free to choose, she would not utterly refuse him. But there was the insuperable obstacle of the purse-proud old man,
who could not endure that a young man of
such limited expectations should pay attention to his daughter.
Underwood slept but little that night. Ile
was dimly conscious of heavy wagons that
rumbled by at intervals, and of bells ringing; but they made little impression on him,
for his thoughts were otherwise occupied.
He arose early and started down town to
his work. As he went down the steps, he
noticed a tangled roll of hose lying in the
gutter. He now remembered the rumblings
during the night.
"It has probably dropped from a passing
truck," he thought, as he opened a basement
window and dropped it in, intending to notify the Fire Department.
Without thinking further of it, he made
his way down town. Accustomed always to
walk, he did not notice that the cars were not
running. As lie began to approach the down
town district, he was awakened from his
reverie by a distant roar, like the sound of
a thousand voices. Looking up, he noticed
for the first time a huge volume of smoke
that spouted up into the sky as if from a
volcano. Quickening his pace, he rapidly
approached the scene of the fire. As he
rounded a corner, a terrifying sight met his
eye. Blocks of smoking ruins stretched before him, and the flames were leaping out
towards buildings yet unconsumed. A large
crowd stood and silently watched the irresistible march of the flames. Soon Underwood found himself in front of a large bank
building. At first, on account of the changed
surroundings, he did not recognize it. But
presently he was able to make out through
the smoke, the inscription over the entrance:
"The Upton National Bank."
His heart gave a great leap. The flames
were eating towards it, and, in all human
probability, the bulk of old Mr. Upton's pos•
sessions would go up in smoke, and—he
hardly dared think it—Edith would be within his reach.

way rapidly through the crowd, and came
running up to the bank building as fast as
the gout would allow. He seemed to be almost besied himself. He ran frantically up
and down, and shouted hoarsely at everybody and everything.
A fire engine. was slowly passing.
"Stop!" cried the old man to the firemen.
"Turn some water on this building."
The engine did not stop.
We have no hose," said one of the lireme".
The old man seemed almost in despair.
There stood a plug just across the street,
but the lack of a little hose seemed destined
to ruin him. The old Mtn seemed stunned.
Ile stood still, and, though it was the month
of February, wiped the perspiration from his
brow. Suddenly an -idea came to him.
"One thousand dollars!" he cried, "to
anyone who will furnish enough hose to save
the bank."
. The crowd seemed motionless, but already
a young man had slipped away unnoticed.
LI a short time he returned, driving madly
down the street in a ricketty wagon. Up
he came pell-mell to the bank, sprang out,
and began to pull hose out of the rear end of
the wagon. Willing hands attached it to
the plug, and then the young nian and the
stout old gentleman together took hold of
the nozzle, and sent a stream of water high
into the air. The water played over the roof
and sides until the building was thoroughly

the adjoining building, and was now ready
to devour the bank; but against soaked walls
and dripping roof it could make no headway.
It changed its course, passed on to the rear,
and left the bank the only building standing in the block.
With a sigh of relief the old man let go
the nozzle, and turned to his companion. The
Young man's hat was gone, his clothes were
torn, and his face was grimy with smoke and
water splashes. But in spite of that, the old
Thall recognized him for the first time as his
daughter's suitoi'.
"Sir," he said haughtily, "come with me,
that I may discharge the debt I owe you."
So saying, he turned, unlocked the door
of the bank, and stepped inside. The interior was intact. He advanced to the office.

As he did so, he looked behind him. To his
surprise, the young man had disappeared.
For two days after the fire, Underwood
confined himself to his room. He felt that,
for the present, he could not seen Edith. On
the third day, a note was brought up to him.
It ran thus:
"Sir:
I would,fain attempt such an impossible
task as that of discharging my indebtedness
to you. If possible, kindly meet me at my
home this evening at eight o'clock.
(Signed) J. T. Upton."
"A plague upon your money," grumbled
Underwood, as he read the note.
But, in spite of himself, something carried
him towards the Upton home that evening,
and, almost without knowing it, he rang the
bell promptly at the hour named. The door
was immediately opened by the old gentleman himself, who had his hat on and carried
his cane in his hand.
"Hub," growled the old man, in his usual
gruff manner, appearing not to recognize
him.
Underwood muttered something about the
"wrong house," and was about to beat a
retreat. But the old gentleman's manner
quickly (hanged.
"My dear Underwood," he said, in the
most cordial tones the young man had ever
heard him use. "I am delighted to see you.
I cannot express my gratitude for your services. It is hardly necessary to say that no
pecuniary reward can possibly liquidate the
obligation.''
"I neither expect nor deserve such a reward," replied the young man modestly.
"We will have to settle it the best we
ran," said the old man abstractedly, and
then continued, "I regret that an engagement will prevent me from conferring further with you at present, but maybe Edith
will take my place." The old man chuckled
a little to himself. "P'r'aps that will suit
you as well," he added, with a twinkle in
his eye as he passed on down the steps.
Then, for the first time, Underwood saw
Edith standing in the hall, waiting to meet
him. She was dressed simply in pure white,
and on her bosom she wore, still in the freshness of its beauty, the little bunch of blue
violets.
J. M. M., '06.

The first of a series of articles to be written for the Ntw:;-LErrim on "Journalism as
a Profession" is contributed this week by
Colonel Thomas P. Grasty. The author is
one of the leaders in the profession, and his
observations upon writing for and conducting a newspaper should prove an inspiration
to those who are considering journalism as
the best and most congenial way of winning
a reputation and earning a livelihood. There
is scarcely a calling in which a man exercises
the power and influence that are vouchsafed
the editors and owners of the great weekly
and daily publications of to-day. Journalism, therefore, offers peculiar and unusual
inducements to the young man who is ambitious, has ideas, is observing and proficient
in the art of writing good, wholesome English. To such men, and there are many in
the University, the series of articles that
we purpose publishing, written from the
standpoint of practical and successful newspaper men should prove of unusual value.
Colonel Grasty's career is interesting in
that, after graduating from Washington and
Lee University, he studied law, and later
abandoned it, after several years of practice,
to go to work as a reporter on the "Courier
Journal." Henry Watterson was then, as
he is now, the editor, and under him Col.

Grasty became familiar with the essential
and fundamental principles of newspaper
making. He rapidly rose from reporter to
staff correspondent, which, from the viewpoint of many journalists, is the most desirable position a newspaper man can hold.
After resigning from the "Courier Journal,"
he edited a number of the best known newspapers in the South and Middle West. Later,
however, he became identified with the
"Manufacturers' Record," of which he is
now vice-president and staff correspondent.
With so broad and varied experience Col.
Grasty's comments on journalism are well
worthy of the careful consideration of those
of our students who plan to make journalism
their profession.

Some weeks ago an article was published
in one of the Baltimore dailies relative to
Dr. Gilman 's resignation as President of the
Carnegie Institution. The "Sun," the daily
that published the story, at the time intimated that perhaps Dr. Gilman had
to resign. The following letter from Dr.
Gilman to the Trustees of the Carnegie Institution is proof positive of the falseness
of the "Sun's" broad headline hint—a hint
based on untruth and actuated apparently
by pure malice.
December 13, 1904.
"To the Trustees of the Carnegie Institution;
"Gentlemen:
At your meeting on December 8, 1903,
I presented to you the following letter:
When I had the honor of being chosen
the first President of the Carnegie Institution, I said to the Trustees that from the nature of the case my tenure of office must be
short, for, having passed the age of seventy
years, I was looking forward to a release
from serious official responsibilities.
The
term of five years was fixed in the By-laws,
and three of them will have passed at the

next annual meeting of the Board. It was
my intention at that time to resign the office
of President, and this early notice is given
in order that the Trustees may be prepared
then to take such action as may seem to
them wise.'
"In accordance with this intimation, I
now resign the office of President of the
Carnegie Institution, and, as the title of the
chief executive may perhaps be changed, I
will add that I am not a candidate for reappointment under any other designation.
"In taking this step, I beg leave to assure
the Board of my continued interest in the
development of this institution, according to
the purposes of the founder; and I express
to the members of the Board, collectively and
individually, my highest respect.
"It has been an honor and a privilege to
be so closely associated as I have been with
with the organization and progress of an institution which bids fair to be a most potent
factor in the advancement of science and in
the encouragement of scientific men.
I'am, Gentlemen,
Very respectfully yours,
DANIEL C. GILMAN."

The Track Team of 1905.
Systematic training in track work has
now begun at the University. Captain Hill,
of the track team, had his men out for the
first practice about three weeks ago, and
practice has continued regularly four times
a week since then. As no games will be held
in the city for at least two months, the track
men will not be subjected to any hard training as yet. Only such an amount of work
will be given them as will keep them in good
condition for beginning hard training in
preparation for any games that may be announced.
There is much good track material in the
University this year, and the prospects for
a good season are very bright. Besides having most of last year's track squad back,
there is some excellent material to be found
among the students who have just entered
the University this fall.
As a nucleus of last year's squad around
which we will build up a very fast team this
year are: Captain Hill, who has made many
records in the short dashes, the running
broad jump, and the hurdles; Glints, who
made good on the relay team; Gilbert, Moreland and. Super in the quarter mile; Clarke,
Goodenow and Zimmerman in the half mile;
and Morse, Porter and Griffith in the mile
run.
Of the new men who have just entered the
University, the one who stands out most
prominently is, perhaps, Betts, in the first
year at the Medical School. Betts comes
from Dickinson College.
While there he

ran on the relay team two years, and captained it one. Ile has often run against
Hopkins, the last time being last spring in
Philadelphia when the Dickinson team ran
a close second to Hopkins. The Hopkins
authorities are greatly elated over having
such an able man with them this year, and
feel that he will be a great addition to the
team. Other new men who have not reached
such a degree of prominence, yet who have
won laurels in local meets are Perce, Stewart,
Padgett, Hunter and Cole. Of this number,
all are dash men with the exception of Cole,
who has attained to sonic prominence in the
880 yard run.
What will give the most trouble in the
track line is the developing of a strong relay
team. Of last year's team, only two remain
—Hill and Gunts ; and, as Hill wishes to
run the short distances only, Glints is practically the only man left. This leaves three
places to be filled, but Captain I ill seems to
have no doubt but what they can be satisfactorily supplied from the new students.
So far, very little has been definitely determined upon in regard to "meets." Besides the dual meet with Virginia, and the
Annual Indoor Meet, held by the University,
negotiations are on for holding dual meets.
with the Naval Academy and Haverford College, respectively. Thus far, nothing definite has been heard from either institution.
The chances are, however, that these meets
will be held here, and if such be the case,
Hopkins men will have the chance of witnessing a rare exhibition of track events.

There was the usual response to the call
for lacrosse candidates, made by Captain Dill
several weeks ago. The scrubs of last year
turned out promptly and were closely followed by men who have had some experience
in the prep. schools, or have had the virtue
of lacrosse pumped into them by some relative who has been fortunate enough to make
our team in the past. But here is where the
good work stopped, and for some days it
seemed as if much good material, as has been
the case in the past, would lie around idle
for a season only to find fault with the older
men for allowing them to waste a year before
taking up the game.
I may say that with the aid of the older
players Captain Dill has managed to add
most of the "I-never-had-a-stick-in-my-handbefore" men to his squad, and they are willing to try.
The seven men that we need, to add to
the five left from last year, so as to make
team for the coming season, have not been
found yet. If all the men "stick to it" we
should come out all right, but at present the
material is still very raw. The coaches have
so far only been putting the men through
preliminary work, but by the first of the year
they hope to be able to get an idea of what
kind of a position each man is suitable for.
In the meantime every man trying to learn
the game can do no better than to utilize
all of his spare time in improving his stickwork. The writer has yet to see a good

Journalism as a Profession.
There are so many kinds of newspaper
work and so many classes of publications,
that any general discussion of this subject
is impossible in the limited space allowed.
Leaving out, however, all kinds and classes
of papers save those of commanding influence and power for good, the field is one in
which what may be called "the personal
equation" will tell the story of success or
failure. And so, if a young man, looking
about for a life vocation, should ask me to
advise him whether or not to adopt journalism as a profession, I should first want to
know that young man better than one father
in a thousand knows his favorite son. I
should want to measure his capacity and
character and test the metal of his ambition.
There is room for usefulness all the way up
from the bottom, but for a man of real ability and ambition the only places in journalism worth having are at the top or very
near the top. These he can never attain
unless endowed by nature with certain peculiar gifts. What Horace said of the poet
is true of the journalist.
It is safe to say that on few other practical questions is the popular idea concerning the requisites for success more vague.
Nine men out of ten, even among the more
intelligent, are under the impression that
the mere ability to write good English is
the main, if not the only, qualification required for successful newspaper work. As
a matter of fact, my observation leads me
to believe that mere ability to write well
is a minor factor in counting up the qualifications for success in this line of work.
The main thing is to know what to write
about—in other words, to know what constitutes news, what the public really wants
to read and be advised about. Some of the
most successful men at the top seldom write
a line. They tell the men at .the bottom
what to say.
Another factor in journalistic success of
scarce less importance than to know what
is news and what to discuss, may be expressed in the single word—character. Love of

truth for truth's sake is indispensable to
commanding influence in this field of human
endeavor. There are hundreds of men with
the gift of knowing how to write and even
of what to write about, and who at the same
time may be real lovers of truth, who can
never reach the top. For your truly great
editor, or manager—or whatever the man
who really controls, directs and inspires a
newspaper may choose to call himself—will
be found to be intensely patriotic and in full
sympathy with his brother man. Indeed, I
make bold to declare that no enduring success was ever made in the upbuilding of
any newspaper or periodical if its real head
lacked either patriotism or philanthropy.
The motto of all permanently great publications is "The greatest good to the greatest
number;'' and is lined up to "without variableness or shadow of turning." The public
does not obey the golden rule to the extent
of doing good for evil. If you prove its
friend, it will be yours. If you are indifferent to its welfare, it is deaf, dumb and blind
to your interests. If you slap it in the face
it will turn upon you and destroy you.
Another desideratum is sense of proportion; a knowledge of relativity. The public is always the final judge of what it
wants. To know what the public wants to
read and be advised about is a condition
precedent to a knowledge of the relative
value of news and of the relative importance
of subjects for editorial discussion. Lack
of this single requisite has kept many a
bright and capable man in a subordinate
The tyro generally
position all his life.
gives the greatest prominence to items and
subjects which appeal to him, and it generally happens that these are the things in
whcih the public is least concerned. "The
proper study of mankind is man" applies
to journalism as to other callings. To keep
in touch with public sentiment it is necessary to study. man collectively.
That the requisites for success in journalism are peculiar and generally little comprehended is attested by the fact that so

It is not perhaps too much to say that there
is a larger percentage of men who after failing in journalism succeed in other lines than
of those who redeem early failure in any

The successful journalist must not only
know the truth, love the truth, know what
is worth while and what is not, have at heart
the public welfare, be imbued with a discerning sense of proportion and relativity,
but he must be progressive, or all these
qualities will count for naught. He who
succeeds in any line must be alert and wide
awake to changing conditions. Every hour
changes the relations of people and things
Ties are sundered,
toward one another.
sympathies are transferred, the old are passing and the new are edging in. The newspaper man, more than all others, is required
to keep in closest touch with ever changing
conditions, to keep familiar with the kaleidoscopic complexities of modern civilization.
The true journalist must be able to discern
the signs of the times as they relate to every
form of human endeavor. He must be the
seer and the prophet, the interpreter and
the orator, the teacher, the preacher. All
this, of course, if he aims at the highest
measure of success.
There are, however, found in newspaper
offices all over the land men who esteem it
to their credit if they have for a number of
years filled the same position on the same
paper, as, for instance, a police reporter or
a "sporting editor," who has become a
local authority in his specialty. Indeed, I
have known various successful "political
editors" who did not even attempt to write
their own stories but who were news gatherers of such marvellous energy and success
that they were regarded as invaluable members of the staff. But these are subordinate
members of the profession.
I am considering this question only from
the standpoint of a college-bred man who is
looking about for a career in life which seems
to him worthy of a high ambition—an ambition which nothing but the highest achievement will satisfy. To such a young man I
should say it is worth while to find out
whether you are endowed with the journalistic instinct. This can be done only by
trying. Begin at the bottom. "Get a job"
as a reporter. Don't for a moment harbor

if your life depended on it. If it be in you

It goes without saying that the career of
a journalist is extremely attractive to the
man of capacity, equipment and high resolve.
Few positions in our national life are more
to be desired than those which have been
held by a Greeley or a Dana or those that
are now held by such men as Henry Watterson or Richard H. Edmonds—types of men
who, though in widely different fields, are
profoundly impressing the thought of to-day
and exerting a powerful influence for good,
as they see it, on the public mind,
In the changing conditions in journalism
as in every other line of endeavor, it may not
be possible for a Greeley, a Dana or a Watterson or an Edmonds to soon appear again

earnest can fail of achieving a certain measure of success, and I really believe there

range of his achievements will be small, if

sympathies and high ideals, he should be
able to organize himself into an efficient journalistic force, though he may never quite
reach the top. With these qualifications he
will be able to write in a manner that the
public will appreciate and understand; he
will be able to treat of the subjects in which
they are interested, and will be able to command their confidence and respect; because

They sat in the farthest corner of the spacious parlor, out of the glare of the brilliant
chandelier. In manly tones, he poured forth
burning words in her ear. She bent her
graceful head, and nervously twirled the
little bunch of blue violets he had brought
her.
But at last she stopped him.
'Harry," she said firmly, "it cannot be.
You know how bitterly father opposes it, and
I must consider his will in the matter. And
then, too," she added, while her bright eyes
filled with tears, "since mother is gone, there
is no one to take care of him but me, and
I cannot desert him now."
On hearing this, Henry Underwood's heart
smote him at the thought that he could wish
to tear this noble girl away from where duty
called her. He wondered how he could find
it in him to press her further; though her
devotion to her gruff old father, raised his
admiration of her, if possible, still higher.
"Edith," he said, as he finally rose to depart, "I can wait. May I also hope?"
Edith Upton. stood in the broad doorway,
her tall shapely figure revealed against the
background of the lighted hall. She did not
answer his question, for, at that moment, a
stout old gentleman, leaning heavily on a
cane, came hobbling up the steps. Henry
instantly recognized him as Mr. Upton, and,
with a word of greeting, was about to pass
out. But the old man blocked his way.
"Young man, whoever you are," he
growled, pretending not to know him,"your
visits here are not welcome."
Underwood was about to make some
haughty reply, but Edith was too quick for
him.
"Father," she said imperatively, catching
him by the arm, "you must not stand here
in the night air. Come inside."
The old man was strangely pliant in her
hands, and soon Underwood saw her pull
him inside and shut the door, not, however,
without giving him a parting look, as he
went slowly down the steps.
It was with a heavy tread that young
Underwood walked home that night. His
affair of the heart had come to a head, and he

had not won. Yet something told him that,
were she free to choose, she would not utterly refuse him. But there was the insuperable obstacle of the purse-proud old man,
who could not endure that a young man of
such limited expectations should pay attention to his daughter.
Underwood slept but little that night. Ile
was dimly conscious of heavy wagons that
rumbled by at intervals, and of bells ringing; but they made little impression on him,
for his thoughts were otherwise occupied.
He arose early and started down town to
his work. As he went down the steps, he
noticed a tangled roll of hose lying in the
gutter. He now remembered the rumblings
during the night.
"It has probably dropped from a passing
truck," he thought, as he opened a basement
window and dropped it in, intending to notify the Fire Department.
Without thinking further of it, he made
his way down town. Accustomed always to
walk, he did not notice that the cars were not
running. As lie began to approach the down
town district, he was awakened from his
reverie by a distant roar, like the sound of
a thousand voices. Looking up, he noticed

volcano. Quickening his pace, he rapidly
approached the scene of the fire. As he
rounded a corner, a terrifying sight met his

The first of a series of articles to be written for the Ntw:;-LErrim on "Journalism as
a Profession" is contributed this week by
Colonel Thomas P. Grasty. The author is
one of the leaders in the profession, and his
observations upon writing for and conducting a newspaper should prove an inspiration
to those who are considering journalism as
the best and most congenial way of winning
a reputation and earning a livelihood. There
is scarcely a calling in which a man exercises
the power and influence that are vouchsafed
the editors and owners of the great weekly
and daily publications of to-day. Journalism, therefore, offers peculiar and unusual
inducements to the young man who is ambitious, has ideas, is observing and proficient
in the art of writing good, wholesome English. To such men, and there are many in
the University, the series of articles that
we purpose publishing, written from the
standpoint of practical and successful newspaper men should prove of unusual value.
Colonel Grasty's career is interesting in
that, after graduating from Washington and
Lee University, he studied law, and later
abandoned it, after several years of practice,
to go to work as a reporter on the "Courier
Journal." Henry Watterson was then, as
he is now, the editor, and under him Col.

Grasty became familiar with the essential
and fundamental principles of newspaper
making. He rapidly rose from reporter to
staff correspondent, which, from the viewpoint of many journalists, is the most desirable position a newspaper man can hold.
After resigning from the "Courier Journal,"
he edited a number of the best known newspapers in the South and Middle West. Later,
however, he became identified with the
"Manufacturers' Record," of which he is
now vice-president and staff correspondent.
With so broad and varied experience Col.
Grasty's comments on journalism are well
worthy of the careful consideration of those
of our students who plan to make journalism
their profession.

adherence to this plan makes it difficult to
take advantage of the character of the
grounds. Another point in which the successful plans excel, is the graceful sweep of
the main avenues, and the ease of access to
any part of the campus from the street or
from the various groups of buildings. The
gymnasium i excellently arranged, facing
in one direction the "forest of dormitories,"
as President Remsen ingeniously called them,
and on the other side opening out directly

Some weeks ago an article was published
in one of the Baltimore dailies relative to
Dr. Gilman 's resignation as President of the
Carnegie Institution. The "Sun," the daily
that published the story, at the time intimated that perhaps Dr. Gilman had
to resign. The following letter from Dr.
Gilman to the Trustees of the Carnegie Institution is proof positive of the falseness
of the "Sun's" broad headline hint—a hint
based on untruth and actuated apparently
by pure malice.
December 13, 1904.
"To the Trustees of the Carnegie Institution;
"Gentlemen:
At your meeting on December 8, 1903,
I presented to you the following letter:
When I had the honor of being chosen
the first President of the Carnegie Institution, I said to the Trustees that from the nature of the case my tenure of office must be
short, for, having passed the age of seventy
years, I was looking forward to a release
from serious official responsibilities.
The
term of five years was fixed in the By-laws,
and three of them will have passed at the

next annual meeting of the Board. It was
my intention at that time to resign the office
of President, and this early notice is given
in order that the Trustees may be prepared
then to take such action as may seem to
them wise.'
"In accordance with this intimation, I
now resign the office of President of the
Carnegie Institution, and, as the title of the
chief executive may perhaps be changed, I
will add that I am not a candidate for reappointment under any other designation.
"In taking this step, I beg leave to assure
the Board of my continued interest in the
development of this institution, according to
the purposes of the founder; and I express
to the members of the Board, collectively and
individually, my highest respect.
"It has been an honor and a privilege to
be so closely associated as I have been with
with the organization and progress of an institution which bids fair to be a most potent
factor in the advancement of science and in
the encouragement of scientific men.
I'am, Gentlemen,
Very respectfully yours,
DANIEL C. GILMAN."

The Track Team of 1905.
Systematic training in track work has
now begun at the University. Captain Hill,
of the track team, had his men out for the
first practice about three weeks ago, and
practice has continued regularly four times
a week since then. As no games will be held
in the city for at least two months, the track
men will not be subjected to any hard training as yet. Only such an amount of work
will be given them as will keep them in good
condition for beginning hard training in
preparation for any games that may be announced.
There is much good track material in the
University this year, and the prospects for
a good season are very bright. Besides having most of last year's track squad back,
there is some excellent material to be found
among the students who have just entered
the University this fall.
As a nucleus of last year's squad around
which we will build up a very fast team this
year are: Captain Hill, who has made many
records in the short dashes, the running
broad jump, and the hurdles; Glints, who
made good on the relay team; Gilbert, Moreland and. Super in the quarter mile; Clarke,
Goodenow and Zimmerman in the half mile;
and Morse, Porter and Griffith in the mile
run.
Of the new men who have just entered the
University, the one who stands out most
prominently is, perhaps, Betts, in the first
year at the Medical School. Betts comes
from Dickinson College.
While there he

ran on the relay team two years, and captained it one. Ile has often run against
Hopkins, the last time being last spring in
Philadelphia when the Dickinson team ran
a close second to Hopkins. The Hopkins
authorities are greatly elated over having
such an able man with them this year, and
feel that he will be a great addition to the
team. Other new men who have not reached
such a degree of prominence, yet who have
won laurels in local meets are Perce, Stewart,
Padgett, Hunter and Cole. Of this number,
all are dash men with the exception of Cole,
who has attained to sonic prominence in the
880 yard run.
What will give the most trouble in the
track line is the developing of a strong relay
team. Of last year's team, only two remain
—Hill and Gunts ; and, as Hill wishes to
run the short distances only, Glints is practically the only man left. This leaves three
places to be filled, but Captain I ill seems to
have no doubt but what they can be satisfactorily supplied from the new students.
So far, very little has been definitely determined upon in regard to "meets." Besides the dual meet with Virginia, and the
Annual Indoor Meet, held by the University,
negotiations are on for holding dual meets.
with the Naval Academy and Haverford College, respectively. Thus far, nothing definite has been heard from either institution.
The chances are, however, that these meets
will be held here, and if such be the case,
Hopkins men will have the chance of witnessing a rare exhibition of track events.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.

There was the usual response to the call
for lacrosse candidates, made by Captain Dill
several weeks ago. The scrubs of last year
turned out promptly and were closely followed by men who have had some experience
in the prep. schools, or have had the virtue
of lacrosse pumped into them by some relative who has been fortunate enough to make
our team in the past. But here is where the
good work stopped, and for some days it
seemed as if much good material, as has been
the case in the past, would lie around idle
for a season only to find fault with the older
men for allowing them to waste a year before
taking up the game.
I may say that with the aid of the older
players Captain Dill has managed to add
most of the "I-never-had-a-stick-in-my-handbefore" men to his squad, and they are willing to try.
The seven men that we need, to add to
the five left from last year, so as to make
team for the coming season, have not been
found yet. If all the men "stick to it" we
should come out all right, but at present the
material is still very raw. The coaches have
so far only been putting the men through
preliminary work, but by the first of the year
they hope to be able to get an idea of what
kind of a position each man is suitable for.
In the meantime every man trying to learn
the game can do no better than to utilize
all of his spare time in improving his stickwork. The writer has yet to see a good
lacrosse player who did not work. "Practice makes perfect."

CHRISTMAS TRIP OF THE MUSICAL
CLUBS.
The Musical Clubs will not go to the Eastern Shore this Christmas, as they have done
for the last two years. The people of the
Eastern Shore town are very good patrons
of concerts, and the last two trips have been
greatly enjoyed by those who were fortunate
enough to be taken on them: But "variety
is the spice of life," and this year Manager
Griswold has decided to take the clubs to
some of the small towns of Maryland and
West Virginia. The men will. leave Baltimore early in the morning of December 27,
and will give concerts at Charlestown, Winchester, Hagerstown, and Frederick.
The Glee Club is unusually strong this
year and several good new songs will be
sung. Among them will be "The Frankelyn's Dogge Leped over a Style," and a new
medley of old Southern airs. Several of the
songs of last year will also be on the programme or will be saved for encores. Of
these, perhaps "Jenks's Vegetable Compound" and "Jemima's Piano," will be most
enjoyed. The Mandolin Club is also excellent this year, and a good repertoire will be
ready for the trip, including a medley of
the latest music, arranged by the leader.
The Banjo Club is somewhat weak in numbers, but the men are working hard, and
much improvement has been shown in the
way the pieces are handled. A medley from
"Red Feather," arranged by V. Edgeworth
Smith, '98, will probably be the Club's most
popular selection.
A vocal quartette has been formed
of Houghton, Plaggemeyer, Holmes and
Ruth, which is certainly one of the best that
has ever represented the University. It is
likely also that there will be a string sextette. Houghton, who added so much to
the success of the trips last year, will sing
several solos, one of which will be accompanied by the Mandolin Club. Bristol,
unfortunately, will not be able to take the
trip, and his solos will be greatly missed.
But, on the whole, the trip bids to be one of
the most successful that the Musical Clubs
have ever experienced.

Great Hannibal was crossing,
The Alps all white with snow,
The path was growing difficult,
The progress was full slow;
(This tale is told by Livy,
Who wrote way long ago.)
Steep, more steep, and steeper,
The narrow pathway grew,
Till finally some towering rocks,
Burst straightway into view;
(And here the army halted,
Just wondering what to do.)
The problem was not easy,
But someone bright did say,
Pour on the rocks some vinegar,
And they will melt away;
(And thus th' affair was ended,
Without the least delay.)
And now in reading Livy,
The best way is to do,
Just like that old barbarian,
When problems came in view;
(And read this very surely:
Perhaps it's meant for you.)
Don't try to ride on ponies,
O'er rocky pathways sore,
For you will get thrown off and strike
That rugged figure 4;
But take your books and o'er it,
Just pore and pore and pore!
